Award.AwardTitle: Potential Fields Pool Equipment Facility: A 5-Year Proposal to Support BGM-3 Gravity Data Acquisition Systems on UNOLS Vessels
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests funding for a 5-year effort to enable PFPE (Potential Field Pool Equipment) to provide the equipment and expertise necessary to continue obtaining high-quality marine gravity data on UNOLS vessels. During the 5-year term of the proposed work, PFPE seeks to (1) maintain adequate spares for operating the BGM-3 gravimeters; (2) provide technical expertise to the UNOLS community; (3) coordinate both the operation and maintenance of systems; and (4) standardize data formats and quality control through the development of a new data logging program. This last effort, software development, will address the need for a standardized data marine gravity format and at-sea data quality assessment but not be a tool for extensive postprocessing of marine gravity data. A key product of this proposal will be the publication of a ?best practices? manual for the UNOLS community. In the development of both item (4) and the ?best practices? manual, we will solicit input both the gravimeter operators and experienced marine gravity users.

Broader Impacts:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data from seagoing gravimeters continues to be an important dataset for solving 21st century earth and ocean science problems. While satellite–derived gravity provides important insights on global-scale earth/ocean research problems, the accuracy and resolution of shipboard gravity data possess superior resolution in both spatial wavelength and resolved gravity measurement. Filtered to wavelengths >15 km, the satellite gravity field agrees with shipboard field within ~3 mgals RMS value averaged over a large region, however, mismatches are substantially larger in areas of steep gradients and/or large anomalies, such as over seamounts or on continental shelves. A good sea surface gravity survey has 1.5 mgals RMS crossover error even over areas of steep gradients down to wavelengths of about 10 km. Over seamounts, the shipboard survey represents about a 90% reduction in variance compared to the satellite data. While there are applications where the satellite data are sufficient, detailed studies of individual seafloor features will continue to require shipboard gravity data collected by marine gravimeters in order to map the gravity field. There continue to be important science justifications for why shipboard gravity is necessary to solve current and future problems in the earth and oceanographic sciences.

  The Potential Fields Pool Equipment (PFPE) supports permanently installed BGM-3, gyro-stabilized gravimeter equipment on all University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) academic research ships. PFPE originated over two decades ago in response to an identified need for the UNOLS community to have a centralized repository for shipboard gravimeter systems’ technical support, and to reduce the overall gravimeter operational and support costs to the federal funding agencies. This effort was formalized in the mid-1990s through a memorandum of understanding between the US Navy Office of Naval Research, NAVOCEANO and the NSF, that was coordinated by Dan Fornari in the Geology & Geophysics Dept. at The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI). In ~2004, Fornari was successful in acquiring NSF funding to purchase used, industry BGM-3 equipment that has served as the backbone of the inventory used to support increased gravity data collection on UNOLS ships – to the point where PFPE now supports gravity equipment and data collection on 9 academic research vessels (Atlantis, Armstrong, Revelle, Sally Ride, Thompson, Siquliaq, Palmer, Healy, Kilo Moana), and has one BGM-3 sensor as a resource for use on other vessels or as a spare for those installed.

  PFPE actively (on a near-daily basis) supports the technicians on UNOLS ships from all the major US oceanographic institutions (e.g., SIO, UW, LDEO, UH, UAF, and WHOI) and Edison-Chouest, which operates the N.B. Palmer and the US Coast Guard, which operates the Healy (Table 1).  In many ways, PFPE is analogous to other oceanographic “community-service” programs that WHOI operates (e.g., the winch/wire pool & NDSF).  For nearly 10 years, PFPE has provided real-time, 24/7 technical support for the BGM-3 gravimeters onboard UNOLS ships via email, telephone and web-based communications.  In addition, part of the funding that has been provided by NSF to support gravimeters on UNOLS ships is directed towards purchasing and refurbishing the gyroscopes, which are an essential/integral component of each BGM-3 system (2 operational per platform, with 2 ready-spares).  The remaining funding provides modest salary for WHOI technical support (3 staff engineers at approximately 1-2 mos./year/person), consulting fees for Mr. Randall Herr, a gravity systems specialist for >40 years, periodic recalibration of the BGM-3 sensors at Lockheed-Martin (L-M), gyro replacement and refurbishment at US Dynamics, and modest travel and shipping to service, install and demobilize gravimeters on UNOLS vessels as required.
